title: Building Reliable Domain-Specific Agents with OpenAI Structured Outputs
summary: This workflow demonstrates how to leverage OpenAI's Structured Outputs update to build highly reliable, domain-specific AI agents. By using Pydantic models to define strict schemas for function calling, the tutorial showcases an image processing agent that generates, converts, and resizes images with 100% schema adherence, eliminating previous reliability issues with tool calling.

steps.reasoning: Wrapping function parameters in Pydantic objects guarantees the LLM responds in the exact format required for execution, ensuring 100% reliability.
Passes the strict schemas (e.g., GenerateImageParams, ResizeImageParams) to the LLM so it understands the available actions and their specific data requirements.
Using Enums (like ImageRatio) narrows down the AI's choices to pre-defined valid values, preventing hallucinations or invalid parameter generation.
The agent translates natural language requests into structured parameters (prompts, quality, ratio) to trigger image generation.
The agent identifies specific file versions from context and applies format conversion logic using the structured output.
Demonstrates granular control by extracting specific integer values (width/height) from the user's request to modify assets.
A `tool_function_map` connects the LLM's structured decision (tool name) to the actual Python logic, closing the loop between intent and action.

key_takeaways: Structured Outputs provide 100% guaranteed schema adherence for function calling, solving previous reliability issues.
Using Enums in data models restricts AI hallucinations and ensures valid parameter selection for critical functions.
Building narrow, domain-specific agents (e.g., image modification) is currently more effective than broad, generic assistants.
The update includes significant cost reductions (50% input, 33% output) for GPT-4o, making agentic workflows more affordable.
